1.2.19  2:04 am   Out of curiosity I slowed down Mount St. Helens to listen more closely to the rhythm of the vocals during the parts where it sounds like you're singing too many syllables over one beat (e.g. "and it's gonna be a" on beat 4 of measure 1). What it seems like you are consistently doing is having three accents during the beat ("AND it's GONna BE a"), but when I listened more closely you aren't doing a triplet feel over the beat, but rather, depending on the words in each particular occurrence, a 3-3-2, 3-2-3, or 2-3-3 pattern of 32nd notes (which fits better with the 16th note rhythms in the instruments than a triplet would). My question is: are you intentionally writing the melody with 32nd note syncopation like that?

      Or are you just thinking about doing 3 accents over the beat? Either way, I'm impressed. Either you're successfully performing a near-impossible rhythm that you've written, or you're naturally creating one by ear as you try to sing with the best feel you can.
1.2.19  1:30 am   how many licks does it take to get to the center of the known universe

1.2.19  12:35 am   there's a thing that comes up among people who are self taught with music or whatever people who do that are said to have "gaps in their knowledge"-stuff people with more formal education learned in school about proper technique or whatever. i always think that's a little strange to say because everybody has gaps in their knowledge, just the people who studied in school have all filled the same gaps. how do you recommend self taught musicians (like me) fill in those gaps? i kinda think if you pay enough attention to how other people do it, and you are somehow very relaxed yet focused, you can pretty much do whatever

1.1.19  7:31 pm   How do you put yourself out there so much? I mean you put so much on this website, do you ever get anxiety about any of it? Like whenever I have a video on YouTube or like a little song on Soundcloud I get worried about people seeing it, or that it's really bad, and I usually end up deleting it. Do you ever delete things you post? How do you just let your personality show and not worry about it?

      (On a unrelated note, where do I find a personality?)
